Slang   Pal. Used as a term of familiar address: "I said to the girl, rather snootily: 'I have a trade, kiddo. I'm a detective'”  ( Ross Macdonald).
Chiefly British & Offensive   A woman or girl.
The supposed wish of a girl or woman to have a penis, postulated by Sigmund Freud as a cause of feelings of inferiority and psychic conflict.
The main character in a picaresque novel when that character is a woman or girl.
A year:  a girl of 13 summers.
a very pretty girl who works as a photographer's model
a preadolescent boy or girl (usually between 9 and 12 years of age)
the quality of being appealing in a delicate or graceful way (of a girl or young woman)
a girl who is a servant
a girl who is a servant
a highly emotional and quick-tempered person (especially a girl or woman)
sexual intercourse with a person (girl or boy) who has not reached the age of consent (even if both parties participate willingly)
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
Offensive & Vulgar Slang   A woman or girl.
Slang   Courage; stamina; perseverance: "She had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand”  ( Mark Twain).
A girl or woman employed to escort people to their seats, as in a theater or stadium.
Used as a courtesy title before the surname or full name of a woman or girl:  Ms. Doe; Ms. Jane Doe.
Offensive Slang   A Jewish-American girl or woman regarded as being pampered or overindulged.
A Latino woman or girl.
A girl or woman.
A girl; a wench.
A rude. wild girl; a tomboy.
the quality of being appealing in a delicate or graceful way (of a girl or young woman)
a day boarder who is a girl
a girl employed to operate an elevator
a girl in a fairy tale who meets a wolf while going to visit her grandmother
a very pretty girl who works as a photographer's model
the childhood of a girl
a professional dancing girl in India
a foreign girl serving as an au pair
(Judaism) an initiation ceremony marking the 12th birthday of a Jewish girl and signifying the beginning of religious responsibility
(Judaism) an initiation ceremony marking the 12th birthday of a Jewish girl and signifying the beginning of religious responsibility
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
United States illustrator remembered for his creation of the `Gibson girl' (1867-1944)
sexual intercourse with a person (girl or boy) who has not reached the age of consent (even if both parties participate willingly)
United States illustrator remembered for his creation of the `Gibson girl' (1867-1944)
a very pretty girl who works as a photographer's model
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
United States illustrator remembered for his creation of the `Gibson girl' (1867-1944)
The young of any animal; also, a young girl; a moppet.

A serving boy; formerly, a youth attending a person of high degree, especially at courts, as a position of honor and education; now commonly, in England, a youth employed for doing errands, waiting on the door, and similar service in households; in the United States, a boy or girl employed to wait upon the members of a legislative body. Prior to 1960 only boys served as pages in the United States Congress.
A word of endearment for a girl or woman.
a ball-shaped cluster of ribbons or streamers held in the hand and waved by some cheerleaders at team sports contests. See pompom girl. Called also pompom.
A boy or a girl under the age of puberty, that is, under fourteen if a male, and under twelve if a female.
A wanton girl; a light wench.
A girl.
To frequent the society of as a suitor or sweetheart: as, to keep company with a girl.
A female professional dancer. See alma, ghawazee, nautch-girl, etc.
A more or less wilful, troublesome, or incorrigible boy or girl, regarded ironically as the rising hope of the family.
Hence A pert or saucy girl or woman; one who is too bold or forward; a minx.
An epithet applied to any one, especially to a boy or girl, in either real or pretended disapproval: sometimes expressing endearment.
A wanton girl; a harlot.
A romping girl; a noisy hoyden; a scold; a violent and vulgar quarrelsome woman.
Specifically— A noisy, riotous person; a roaring boy or girl. See roaring, p. a. [Old London slang.]

A person, usually a woman or girl, who formerly carried coal in baskets from the workings to the shaft, and in many cases up the ladders to the surface. The bearer was usually the miner's wife or daughter.
In law, the guardian of a boy or girl in pupilarity.

A boy who is a member of the Campfire Boys and Girls, an organization for children aged 7 through 18 that strives to instill good values and teach practical skills. Before 1975, the organization was limited to girls.
a swelling over the knee, due to an enlargement of the bursa in the front of the kneepan; -- so called because frequently occurring in servant girls who work upon their knees.
A man or young man; a fellow; -- usually contrasted with <contr>gals</contr> or <contr>girls</contr> .
Movements and evolutions performed in concert by a company of girls or ladies armed with fans.
One who ‘fusses’ over girls; a particularly active beau.
A rustic festival in which girls carry on their heads kits decorated with willow.
In Greek antiquity, a song sung by girls accompanied by the flute.
A porcelain wine-cup made by Chinese potters and decorated with figures of girls swinging.
A ribbon, braid, or the like made for the wear of country girls. Compare tawdry, a.
An ornamental band or ring, for the wrist or the arm; in modern times, an ornament encircling the wrist, worn by women or girls.
A young man who makes a business of ruining girls to put them in brothels.
The livelong, Sedum Telephium: said to have been used by girls on midsummer eve to test their lovers' fidelity.
A society of women or girls who meet regularly to sew for the benefit of charitable or religious objects.
In Greek antiquity, a roll, knot, or tuft of hair on the top of the head, a mode practised especially by girls and young women.
In Brittany, one of the tiny fairies reputed to frequent druidical remains and to delight in beguiling young girls.
A member of an order of nuns of the Roman Catholic Church, founded in the early 16th century and devoted to the education of girls.
An elasticized fabric ring used chiefly by women and girls to gather or fasten the hair.
Chiefly British   A graduate of a public school for girls.
A school of higher education, especially a private school for girls.
A loose garment worn in bed by women and girls. Also called nightdress.
A similar skirt worn by women, girls, and boys.
A dance or party to which girls invite boys.
A close-fitting, often short T-shirt worn especially by young women and teenage girls.
skintight knit hose covering the body from the waist to the feet worn by acrobats and dancers and as stockings by women and girls
masculinity in women (especially in girls and young women)
snug trousers ending at the calves; worn by women and girls
An overnight party in which guests, usually girls, wear nightclothes, socialize, and spend the night at a friend's home.
A private girls' school that stresses training in cultural subjects and social activities.
A sleeveless garment similar to an apron, worn especially by small girls as a dress or an overdress.
The period of childhood just before the onset of puberty, often designated as between the ages of 10 and 12 in girls and 11 and 13 in boys.
snug trousers ending at the calves; worn by women and girls
A costume formerly worn by women and girls that was composed of loose trousers gathered about the ankles and worn under a short skirt.
A place in the country that offers simple group accommodations and organized recreation or instruction, as for vacationing children:  a girls' summer camp; a tennis camp.
A one-piece outer garment for women or girls.
A class of clothing sizes for girls and slender women. Also called junior miss.
an organization of young women and girls founded in 1912 for character development and citizenship training
a sleeveless tunic worn by English girls as part of a school uniform
a decorative hinged clip that girls and women put in their hair to hold it in place
masculinity in women (especially in girls and young women)
skintight knit hose covering the body from the waist to the feet worn by acrobats and dancers and as stockings by women and girls
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls
Chlorosis in girls.

a religious order founded in Dublin in the year 1827. Communities of the same name have since been established in various American cities. The duties of those belonging to the order are, to attend lying-in hospitals, to superintend the education of girls, and protect decent women out of employment, to visit prisoners and the sick, and to attend persons condemned to death.

an East Indian plant (Mantisia saltatoria) of the Ginger family, sometimes seen in hothouses. It has curious flowers which have some resemblance to a ballet dancer, whence the popular name. Called also dancing girls.

A white robe with a purple border, worn by a Roman boy before he was entitled to wear the toga virilis, or until about the completion of his fourteenth year, and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by magistrates and priests.

word: the order of the visitation of our lady
definition: a religious community of nuns, founded at Annecy, in Savoy, in 1610, and in 1808 established in the United States. In America these nuns are devoted to the education of girls.
One of four young girls of noble birth who were chosen annually in ancient Athens to dwell on the Acropolis and attend the priestess of Athena Polias.
A fillet worn round the head; a head-band; especially, a ribbon worn by girls and women above the forehead.
A group or small company of persons, especially of girls or women, but also used of the male sex: as, “a bevy of powdered coxcombs,” Goldsmith; “a bevy of renegades,” Macaulay, Hist. Eng.
plural A kind of waistcoat, stiffened with whalebone or other material, now worn chiefly by women and girls to support and give shape to the body, but formerly worn also by men.

A game in which children, especially girls, stand in a row holding hands, and the outer one, still holding the one next, runs between the others under their uplifted hands, and is followed by the rest in turn. Also called thread and needle.
A small cape resem—bling a very broad collar, worn by women and girls in the first quarter of the nineteenth century.

A diminutive suffix, appearing chiefly in childish names of animals, etc., as kitty, doggy, piggy, birdy, froggy, mousy, and similar names, or familiar forms of personal names, as Katy or Kitty (diminutive of Kate), Jenny, Hetty, Fanny, Willy, Johnny, Tommy, etc., such names being often spelled with -ie, as Willie, Davie, etc., a spelling common in Scotch use, and also in general use in names of girls, as Katie, Jennie, Hettie, Carrie, Lizzie, Nellie, Annie, etc.
A man who busies himself with affairs which properly belong to women.
The qualities idealized by knighthood, such as bravery, courtesy, honor, and gallantry toward women.

Formerly, a man who dealt in articles for women's wear; according to Johnson, “one who sells ribands and dresses for women”; now, in common usage, a woman who makes and sells bonnets and other head-gear for women; also, in England, one who furnishes both bonnets and dresses, or complete outfits.

One of a community of women engaged in religious and charitable work. Such communities are the oblates founded by St. Francesca of Rome about 1433, and the Oblate Sisters of Providence, a sisterhood of colored women founded at Baltimore in 1825 for the education and the amelioration of the condition of colored women.
Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women.

A kind of loose robe or gown tied with a sash, worn as a traditional outer garment by Japanese women and men. Women may wear it with a broad sash called an obi, having a large bow in the back. At present (1998), most Japanese wear it only at home or on ceremonial occasions, western-style clothing being more common in the workplace.
Among the South African Dutch, a title of women, especially of young women, equivalent to Madame, or Mistress (Mrs.).
An amended spelling of women.

An opinion or position reached by a group as a whole: "Among political women . . . there is a clear consensus about the problems women candidates have traditionally faced”  ( Wendy Kaminer).  See Usage Note at redundancy.
The right of women to vote; exercise of the franchise by women.
A nonsteroidal estrogen antagonist used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer in women whose tumors are estrogen-dependent and also used prophylactically by some women at risk for breast cancer.
difficulty in beginning the flow of urine; associated with prostate enlargement in men and with narrowing of the urethral opening in women; may be caused by emotional stress in either men or women
Something required or wanted; a requisite: "Those of us who led the charge for these women's issues ... shared a common vision in the needs of women”  ( Olympia Snowe).
a compound found in women's urine during certain phases of the menstrual cycle and in the urine of pregnant women
a code that permits greater sexual freedom for men than for women (associated with the subordination of women)
Originally, a loosely hanging garment for women, worn like a cloak about the shoulders, and serving as a decorative appendage to the gown; now, an outer garment with sleeves, worn by women.

A linen covering for the throat and breast, sometimes also for the lower part of the face, worn by women throughout the middle ages in western Europe. It was at times peculiar to nuns or women in mourning.
In Roman antiquity, one of the two tunics commonly worn by both men and women, probably the outer tunic, though some archæologists have contended that it was the inner tunic of the women.
The industry of making bonnets and other head-dresses for women. This work was formerly in the hands of men, but is now almost exclusively a women's occupation.

The term cancer, as commonly employed, includes those new growths which possess certain attributes that render them especially dangerous to life, and which are therefore called malignant. Malignant tumors growby infiltration and destruction of the surrounding tissues, and are characterized by a tendency to recur after removal, by the property of spreading to other parts of the body by a process of dissemination known as metastasis, and by producing a general disturbance of health termed cachexia. From the standpoint, of the pathologist two chief groups of cancerous tumors are recognized: the carcinomata, or true cancers, and the sarcomata. The fundamental difference between these two is the fact that carcinoma originates in the epithelial tissues of the body, whereas sarcoma develops from the connective tissues. This difference in origin gives rise to certain structural characteristics which enable the microscopist readily to distinguish one type from the other. Carcinoma is rare before the age of thirty; it is somewhat commoner in women than in men; and it is most often seen in the uterus, skin, breast, and stomach. Sarcoma is a disease of early adult life, is more prone to attack men than women, and is commonly found in the subcutaneous tissue, bony structures, and lymph-nodes. Carcinoma is conveyed from one part of the body to another through the lymphatic vessels, sarcoma by way of the blood-stream. In spite of an enormous amount of research devoted to this subject, the exciting cause of cancer is still unknown. The influences of heredity, climate, food, race, social condition, and local injury have all been invoked as factors concerned, but without arriving at any degree of certainty. The theory referring the developmentof malignant tumors to the presence of minute animal or vegetable organisms has numerous adherents, but it has not been definitely established, and many prominent authorities consider that the explanation is to be sought for in a disturbance of some still undiscovered fundamental law governing the growth of cells. Although it appears that cancer is increasing somewhat in frequency, the percentage of cures is increasing much more rapidly, owing to the earlier diagnoses and more thorough operations which are now possible. Extirpation by the knife as promptly and as completely as possible, when the growth is accessible, is regarded as the method of treatment that offers the greatest hope of a cure; but the employment of the X-rays or other form of radioactivity has in a number of instances given excellent results.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.
A man with a belief in the inferiority of women; one who believes in or practises male chavinism.
An arrangement of lace or tulle, looped ornamentally, and worn by women on the front of the dress.
A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face, worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
The section of a hospital devoted to assisting women during childbirth and caring for them and their newborn infants until they are released to go home.
a jury of experienced women called to determine the question of pregnancy when set up in bar of execution, and for other cognate purposes.

A strong, and by some considered exaggerated, sense of manly pride, associated with an attitude that the proper expression of masculinity includes virility, courage, and an entitlement to dominate, especially over women.
a small dressy handbag, richly decorated, carried by women for formal occasions in the evening.
A form of the escutcheon used by women instead of the shield which is used by men.
A fabric of wool and cotton with a lustrous surface, -- used for women's dresses.
A charmer of women.
The pubic area; the genitalia, especially in women.
A short cloak or mantle worn by women.
One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
a boat race in which the crews are composed of a number of pairs, usually of men and women.

a standard or set of principles governing conduct, which is applied more stringently or differently to one group of people than to another; -- used especially of standards of sexual behavior that condemn behavior on the part of women that is condoned or not condemned when exhibited by men.
A demon; a fiend; a lascivious spirit, supposed to have sexual intercourse with women by night.
One of a sect of Anabaptists, in the fifteenth and early part of the sixteenth century, who rejected many of the customs and decencies of life, and advocated a community of goods and of women.
One who dangles about or after others, especially after women; a trifler.
A kind of fabric for women's dresses.
a device shaped like an erect penis, used by some women for sexual stimulation.
A women who plays in comedy.
A nocturnal festivity with which the Australian aborigines celebrate tribal events of importance. Symbolic dances are given by the young men of the tribe, while the women act as musicians.
In the Middle Ages, a gown or basque of which the body was close fitting, worn by both men and women.
A kind of woolen material for women's skirts.
A square piece of linen used formerly by women instead of a cap; a kerchief.
A public nursery, where the young children of poor women are cared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
A kind of stiff cloth, used chiefly by women, for underskirts, to expand the gown worn over it; -- so called because originally made of hair.
An act of civility, respect, or reverence, made by women, consisting of a slight depression or dropping of the body, with bending of the knees. Same as 2nd courtesy, n..
a cap with wings, formerly worn by women.
Goat, seal, and other skins blacked on the grain side for women's shoes, etc.
That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women.
The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women; same as gynecology.
a small net that some women wear over their hair to keep it in place.

a small bag usually made of cloth, leather or a similar imitation material, and often having a strap to permit carrying it by slinging it over a shoulder, used by women to carry money and small personal items or accessories.
A covering for the head; esp., one with a crown and brim, made of various materials, and worn by men or women for protecting the head from the sun or weather, or for ornament.
a long sturdy pin used by women to secure a hat to their hair.
A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
A thin silk or woolen goods, for women's dresses, woven in various styles and colors.
A supposed primitive state of society, in which all the women of a tribe were held in common.
Purity; chastity; -- a term applied mostly to women, but becoming uncommon in usage.
a loose dressing gown for women.
A square of fine linen worn by women as a covering for the head; hence, anything similar in form or material, worn for ornament on other parts of the person; -- mostly used in compounds
A linsey-woolsey fabric having a rough knotted surface on the right side; used for women's dresses.
A gallant who captivates the hearts of women.
The art or practice of captivating the hearts of women.
A species of very durable woolen stuff, used for women's shoes; everlasting.
A printed cloth garment resembling a skirt or kilt, worn as the principle garment by both men and women in Polynesia, especialy in Samoa; called also pareu.
A cap or coif worn by women.
A loose outer garment, extending from the neck downwards, and commonly without sleeves. It is longer than a cape, and is worn both by men and by women.
A thin worsted fabric for women's dresses.
A thin gauzelike fabric of silk or wool, for women's wear.
A small spot on the front wall of the vagina in women, reported to be exceptionally able to produce high sexual excitement or orgasm when stimulated. Its existence is not universally accepted.
A similar jacket, usually ornamented, with or without sleeves, worn by women.
A gymnasium; esp. one for light physical exercise by women and children.
A short dressing jacket for women.
A long outer garment formerly worn by men and women, as well as by soldiers as part of their uniform.
A covering of network for the head, worn by women; also, a net.
small lumpy deposits of body fat esp. on women's thighs and buttocks. Not used as a technical term.
A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers united in one.
A shift, or undergarment, worn by women.
An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck, shoulders, and breast.
A sentimental motion picture that appeals particularly to women.  See flick, n., movie.
A bunch, knot, or rosette of ribbon or other material, used as an ornament in women's dress.
A ruff worn by women.
A fabric with a silk warp and a wool or cotton weft, so woven as to throw the silk on the face: used for umbrellas and women's dress-goods.
A light, fine cotton or linen fabric of open texture for women's dresses.
A fancy fabric with a cotton warp and a wool weft for women's wear.
A form of marriage in which a group of menare considered the husbands of a group of women.
In pathology, excessive hairiness, especially in women.
In Greek antiquity, a water-carrying; a group of women carrying water from a fountain: a subject often represented on the Greek hydria, or water-pots.
A garment, worn by Moro women, formed of a long piece of cloth, sewed together at the ends, which is wrapped about the body in various ways.
A head-dress worn by women in the reign of Henry VIII.
The women of a family or party. Compare womankind.
A light-weight fabric of silk and wool for women's wear.
A fine, sheer fabric of either silk or cotton, used for women's neckwear and for ruching.
A sort of sling or support by means of which the native Australian women carry their children on their backs.
Man-hatred; a bad opinion of man, as being unfair or oppressive toward women.
A fabric for women's wear, having a satinarmure weave.
A room or ward in a hospital or other public institution where women are cared for during parturition.
A nose-ring worn by East Indian women as a badge of widowhood.
A wool-and-cotton fabric for women's wear.
Formerly, the principal garment of the women of Hawaii, consisting of a number of pieces of tapa, generally five, wound around the waist and reaching to about the knee.

A closed carriage with two or four wheels, used by Roman women. Like similar medieval wagons it was arranged with entrance doors in the middle on both sides. Two or three pilenta are represented on the column of Theodosius at Constantinople.
In the Philippine Islands, a knot of hair held together by a comb, worn by Tagalog women.
In a Greek dwelling-house, a vestibule leading to the women's apartments: apparently, any open lobby, as between two piers or antæ.

Specifically, a periodical social gathering of men and women representative of the wit, fashion, literature, art, or politics of the time. The salon flourished principally in France during the eighteenth century.
A material for women's gowns, worn in the eighteenth century.
A soft, silky flannel for women's dresses.
A sisterhood, corresponding to fraternity: often applied to women's Greek letter societies.
A loose gown (or a roll of cotton for the purpose) worn by native women in Egypt under the habara or cloak.
An ancient ornamented head-dress for women.
A kind of semilunar knife used by Eskimo women.
Apparently a heavy repped woolen goods, which was much used for women's winter gowns in Colonial days.
A very thin muslin, so open in texture as to be transparent, and often rather coarse in quality. It is used for women's evening dress, for widows' caps, etc.
A jacket worn by Eskimo men and women. See jumper.
A kerchief or veil of semi-transparent material, worn by women at the close of the eighteenth century.
A head-dress for women.
A stout twilled silk textile employed for women's dresses, and considered very durable.
A close linen or woolen cap, without lace, frill, or border, and with flaps covering the neck and part of the shoulders, worn chiefly by old women. Also toy.
A sash of silk, or silk and cotton, usually red, worn by women in Burma.
A leather prepared by oil-tawing without first removing the hair side, the flesh side being blackened in the usual way: used for women's boots and shoes.
A style of dressing women's hair in fashion about 1850, the hair being drawn back from the forehead, and forming a roll on the crown of the head.
Woolen cloth made from the wool of the vicugna. It is very soft, and is especially employed for women's clothes.
A full sleeve worn by women about tho middle of the seventeenth century.
An outer garment worn by women in the first half of the nineteenth century, thin, made of silk or like material, and shaped to the person.
A dress for the street; especially, at the present time, such a dress for women, as distinguished from a dinner-dress, an evening-dress, etc.
Originally, a blanket; later, a coarse shaggy mantle or woolen shawl worn by West-country women in England.
One who or that which makes widows by bereaving women of their husbands.
One who has an aversion to women in general; a misogynist.
One who kills women. See manqueller.
The exercise of the electoral franchise by women.
Woolen cloth woven with flowers and other patterns in a light matelassé silk. It is used for women's outer garments.
A small bag of some textile material, formerly carried by women, and used to contain their needlework. The term was often used for the reticule.

A basket used by women either to hold the implements for sewing, as needles, thread, scissors, or thimble, in which case the basket is small, or to hold partly made garments, articles needing repair, etc., for which use the basket is large and has a wide opening.
A box used by women to hold their materials for sewing and the needlework itself when not too bulky.
A room for working in, especially one in which women are employed.
The veil worn by Moslem women in public—that is, when not in their own apartments.
A name of contempt given to a man who interferes with the duties of women in a household, or who occupies himself with womanish matters.
A kind of under waist stiffened with whalebone, etc., worn esp. by women; a corset; stays.
A kind of small outer jacket, with or without sleeves, worn by women.
A scolding bridle, an instrument formerly used for correcting scolding women. It was an iron frame surrounding the head and having a triangular piece entering the mouth of the scold.
An ornament, in various forms, with a tongue, pin, or loop for attaching it to a garment; now worn at the breast by women; a breastpin. Formerly worn by men on the hat.

a disordered eating habit characterized by occasional episodes of excessive eating, followed by self-induced vomiting or abuse of laxatives, to avoid gaining weight; it is often accompanied by feelings of guilt; -- called also bulimia nervosa and binge-purge syndrome. It is observed mainly in young women of normal weight.
A combination cloak and hood worn by women.

Among the Creek Indians, a feast of first fruits celebrated when the corn is ripe enough to be eaten. The feast usually continues four days. On the first day the new fire is lighted, by friction of wood, and distributed to the various households, an offering of green corn, including an ear brought from each of the four quarters or directions, is consumed, and medicine is brewed from snakeroot. On the second and third days the men physic with the medicine, the women bathe, the two sexes are taboo to one another, and all fast. On the fourth day there are feasting, dancing, and games.
A kind of pad or cushion worn on the back below the waist, by women, to give fullness to the skirts; -- called also bishop, and tournure.
the gift or power of producing a glamour. The former is used figuratively, of the gift of fascination peculiar to women.
A milliner of the male sex; especially, one who undertakes the manufacture of women's bonnets, etc., employing others to do the work.
A loose outer garment worn by women.
A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in women's costume.
A loose gown or wrapper worn by women in the sixteenth century. It was used especially as an outer garment over the robe.
The final cessation of the menses or monthly courses of women, which occurs normally between the ages of forty-five and fifty; the end of menstruation.
A woolen material for women's dresses and cloaks, usually having a narrow stripe.
The practice of obstetrics; the practice of assisting women in childbirth.
A pickpocket who robs women only.
A Mohammedan inhabitant of Malabar in southwestern India, descended from Arabs who settled there and married native women.
A cap worn during the day, on other than ceremonial occasions; especially, a cap worn by women in the morning to cover and protect the hair.
A room used by the women of a family as a boudoir or sitting-room, and supposed to be occupied only before dinner.
A loose full gown worn by women: so named from its general resemblance to that considered characteristic of “Mother Hubbard” in the rimes of “Mother Goose.”
A brooch of jet or other suitable material, worn by women as a sign of mourning.
A small muff worn over the wrist; a wristband of fur or worsted worn by women.
Excessive fondness for women.
A muslin of the finest quality, thin, soft, and transparent, used for women's dresses and the like. The name is usually given to the English and other imitations of mull. See mull.

One of a band of dissolute young fellows who, in the reign of Queen Anne, swaggered by night in the streets of London, breaking windows, overturning sedans, beating men, and offering rude caresses to women; a Mohawk.
A neck-handkerchief, specifically that worn by women in the eighteenth century.
The servitude, bondage, or villeinage of women.
A long close-fitting coat for women's outdoor wear, usually made of broadcloth.
A part of women's dress, probably a veil, worn in the latter part of the fifteenth century.
Numbness of the extremities coming on at night: it occurs sometimes in women at the menopause.
A defense for the nipple worn by nursing women.
One of several varieties of bunting used for women's gowns.
An untwilled woolen fabric, very soft, fine, and thin, used by women for veils, and also for dresses, etc.
A muslin of great fineness and translucency, used for women's dresses. It is sold both plain and figured with printed flowers, etc.
A smooth, strong, rich silk, originally manufactured at Padua, used for garments of both women and men in the eighteenth century; also, a garment made of this material.
A kind of straw bonnet for women, introduced about 1850.
In the costume of the seventeenth century, a partial wig; a front of curls, or the like, worn by women when not in full dress.
A cluster of curls or loose locks of hair on the temple: a style of dressing women's hair in the early part of the eighteenth century.
A lover of women: the opposite of misogynist.
In civil and Scots law, the crime of stealing men, women, or children, formerly punishable with death.
In textile fabrics, a pattern of round dots or spots, especially in printed stuffs for women's wear.
A knitted jacket worn by women.
A loose gown formerly worn by men and women to protect their clothes when having the hair powdered; a dressing-gown.
A kind of lasting of which clergymen's gowns were once made, now rarely used except for the uppers of women's shoes. Also called everlasting.
A head-dress for women, derived from the East, probably the Levant, and adopted in Spain in the thirteenth century. It was practically an upright and nearly cylindrical hat.
A cap worn by women in the eighteenth century, apparently a form of the mob-cap: the name is taken from Ranelagh, a place of fashionable resort near Dublin.

A piece of dress among the ancient Romans, consisting of a mantle, smaller and shorter than the pallium, and having a cowl or hood for the head attached to it. It was worn especially by women, particularly as a morning garment, and by mimes on the stage.
A hood used by women in the eighteenth century, and perhaps earlier, when traveling or exposed to the weather, the use of it depending on the style of head-dress or coiffure in fashion of the time.
A separate skirt fastened around the waist over the other dress, worn by women in riding.
A light wrap sometimes worn by women upon the head; a head-covering resembling a scarf rather than a hood, and usually knitted or crocheted of wool.
A loose open jacket for women, usually of silk or some rather thick material.
An evening party in the country: so called from the practice once prevalent among the women of taking their rocks (distaffs) with them and spinning.
A man devoted to a life of pleasure and sensuality, especially in his relation to women; a debauchee; a rake.
A sort of jacket with skirts or tails extending about to the knee, worn by women in the seventeenth century.
Unnatural sexual relations between women.
A thin woolen cloth with a smooth and glossy face, used especially for women's gowns.
A silk textile material made in India, with a glossy surface: it is used for women's clothes.
A diseased and unrestrainable venereal appetite in men, corresponding to nymphomania in women.
A seraglio, or place of seclusion for women.
A light woolen stuff used for the linings of coats and for women's dresses.
A mantle or cloak for women's wear, made of a shawl, and usually very simple in its cut, having no sleeves, and often resembling the burnoose.
A textile of silk and wool used for dresses and parts of dresses for women. The material is soft and flexible, and is usually woven in designs of Oriental character.
A garment for women's and children's wear, resembling a shirt in fashion, but worn over the underclothing, and extending no lower than the waist, where it is belted.
A loose, light robe, worn by women: only in poetical use, without precise meaning.
A loose morning-gown worn by women about the middle of the eighteenth century. It was trimmed with cuffs and ruffles of lace.
A kind of false birth fabled to be produced by Dutch women from sitting over their stoves (Johnson)′ , hence, an abortive scheme or attempt.
An accumulation of fat on the buttocks of certain Africans, especially Hottentot women.
An outdoor game of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, generally played by women alone, but sometimes in company with men. See second quotation.
The character or quality of being strong-minded, especially as used of women.
A soft twilled silk material, usually of plain uniform color without pattern, used for women's garments, etc.
Black sulphuret of antimony, used by Moslem and Hindu women for darkening the eyes. See kohl.
A many-colored wrap or rectangular piece of woolen cloth used by the Indian women of Bolivia for carrying their children on the back. Compare atado.
A member of a sect of the 7th century who condemned all intercourse with women.
A small flat curl worn by women on the temples.
A fine, corded dress-fabric for women's wear.
A shirt; a chemise; specifically, a waist made of piña, white or dyed, embroidered, and with loose sleeves, worn by the native women of the Philippine Islands.
A member of the Carmelite order of women.
In Spanish-speaking countries, a slipper; in the Philippine Islands, a native slipper without a heel and with a very small upper which barely covers the toes: worn by women.
A somewhat similar jacket worn by women.
Joint education; specifically, the education of young men and young women in the same institution and the same classes.
A long-term, intimate, sometimes discreetly sexual relationship between two women.
A man who ardently seeks the company and affection of women.
A chronic inflammation of the lachrymal and salivary glands, often accompanied by rheumatoid arthritis and the presence of autoantibodies in the blood, occurring chiefly among women.
Slang   The man who would make an ideal mate: "self-help guides for women in search of Mr. Right”  ( Los Angeles Times).
A loose, usually black robe worn by Muslim women, especially in Arabic-speaking regions, covering the body from head to toe and often worn with a headscarf and veil.
The administration of estrogen and progestin to women to relieve the symptoms of menopause, prevent osteoporosis, and reduce the risk of heart disease.
An advocate of the extension of political voting rights, especially to women.
A very brief, close-fitting two-piece bathing suit worn by women.

A psychophysiological disorder usually occurring in young women that is characterized by an abnormal fear of becoming obese, a distorted self-image, a persistent unwillingness to eat, and severe weight loss. It is often accompanied by self-induced vomiting, excessive exercise, malnutrition, amenorrhea, and other physiological changes.
A rectangular woolen or linen cloak worn by men and women in ancient Greece.
A synthetic drug analogue of pyrophosphate that acts primarily on bone to inhibit its resorption and is used to treat and prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.
The traditional dress of Vietnamese women, consisting of a long tunic that is slit on the sides and worn over loose trousers.
The business of designing, making, and selling highly fashionable, usually custom-made clothing for women.
Line of descent as traced through women on the maternal side of a family.
A long cotton outer garment, usually white, traditionally worn by Muslim women.
Evening attire and accessories for women.
Informal   Photographs of minimally attired women.
A long dress with a high collar and slit skirt, traditionally worn by Chinese women.
A lightweight lace or silk scarf worn over the head and shoulders, often over a high comb, by women in Spain and Latin America.
A loose, usually black robe worn by Muslim women that covers the body from head to toe.
A tight-fitting one-piece garment for women usually made of leather or a synthetic fabric such as spandex and covering the torso, legs, and sometimes the arms.
A loose, usually black or light blue robe that is worn by Muslim women, especially in Afghanistan, and that covers the body from head to toe.
A familiar name for an aunt. In the southern United States a familiar term applied to aged negro women.

The doctrine of a modern religious pantheistical sect in Persia, which was founded, about 1844, by Mirza Ali Mohammed ibn Rabhik (1820 -- 1850), who assumed the title of Bab-ed-Din (Per., Gate of the Faith). Babism is a mixture of Mohammedan, Christian, Jewish, and Parsi elements. This doctrine forbids concubinage and polygamy, and frees women from many of the degradations imposed upon them among the orthodox Mohammedans. Mendicancy, the use of intoxicating liquors and drugs, and slave dealing, are forbidden; asceticism is discountenanced.
An artistic dance performed as a theatrical entertainment, or an interlude, by a number of persons, usually women. Sometimes, a scene accompanied by pantomime and dancing.

An ornamental circlet, of glass, gold, silver, or other material, worn mostly by women, upon the wrist or ankle; a ring bracelet. It differs from other bracelets in being rigid and not articulated, in contrast to bracelets made of links.
The practice of procuring women for the gratification of lust.
A small flat curl worn on the temple by women.

A social club for male college undergraduates. They often have secret initiation rites, and are named by the use of two or three Greek letters. The corresponding association for women students is called a <contr>sorority</contr>.
a fringe of hair or curls worn about the forehead by women.
A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn by women under the hair to stuff it out.

A loose outer garment; especially, a gown forming a part of European modern costume for women and children; also, a coarse shirtlike garment worn by some workmen over their other clothes; a smock frock.
That which covers the foremost part of the head: a front piece of false hair worn by women.
A jacket worn by women; -- so called from its resemblance in shape to the red shirt worn by the Italians patriot Garibaldi.
A soft covering for the head, worn by women, which leaves only the face exposed.
A sleeveless one-piece dress, either with full shoulders or straps, sometimes with only the front part of the bodice, usually worn by women with a blouse underneath.
A preparation of antimony used by the women of Eastern nations to darken the eyelids and eyelashes.
A pimp; a kept gallant; a page who waited on loose women.
A long robe or tunic girded at the waist, worn by women in Scotland as late as 1740. Planché. Also airisad, airisard.
A kind of taffeta or plain silk, used for women's and also for men's wear in the eighteenth century and earlier.
A pouch or purse, often richly embroidered, carried at the girdle by persons of rank during the middle ages. The name is also given to a bag or pouch similarly worn by women at the present day.
A strip of plaited muslin or lace placed inside of the bottom of women's dresses to protect them from the floor.
A light mixed fabric of cotton and wool for women's dresses, commonly used for summer gowns before the introduction of barege.
An outer petticoat worn by Basque and Spanish women.
A patch or spot placed on the face to heighten beauty, as formerly practised by women; hence, something that heightens beauty by contrast; a foil.
A thin stuff made of silk and hair, used for women's apparel: formerly made in Bengal.
A kind of jacket, made of an entire deer-skin, worn by the women of the Apaches. L. Hamilton, Mex. Handbook, p. 49.
A head-dress formerly worn by the women of the Irish peasantry, described as a kind of kerchief.
A peculiar wide form of sleeve formerly worn by women: so named from its resemblance to the full sleeve, drawn in at the wrist, worn by Anglican bishops.
A shade formerly worn by women on the front of a bonnet to protect the complexion from the sun; also, a large bonnet or broad-brimmed hat serving the same purpose.
A trade-name for a half or short boot for women.
A linen vestment similar to a rochet, formerly worn by women over their other clothing.
A small cap, usually made of muslin or lace and ribbons, worn at breakfast by married women.
A small comb used to secure the curls called buckles worn by women.
A projecting or puffed-out covering of gauze or linen for the breast, much worn by women about the middle of the eighteenth century.
A part of a head-dress worn by women in the eighteenth century, described as a roll at the back of the head.
A kind of dance performed in low resorts by men and women, who indulge in extravagant postures and lascivious gestures; hence, a quadrille or a similar dance performed in this manner.
A large loose hood worn by women in the eighteenth century.
A textile fabric for women's dresses, made with a soft and glossy surface, in imitation of cashmere.
A bridle with double reins used by women.
A kind of gingham in plain colors with linen finish, used for women's gowns.
In India, a small circular ornament worn by women on the forehead, between the eyes. It may be of metal or fine stone, or merely a mark made with an unguent or cosmetic.
A sort of muffler worn by women in the time of Charles I.
In ancient Greek costume, a small mantle of light stuff, apparently a small chlæna, worn by women.
The practice of acting as, or the custom of having, a cicisbeo; the practice of dangling about women.
A wooden clog or patten worn by women in Egypt and the Levant.
A thin fabric of worsted and cotton, or worsted and silk, twilled on one side, used for women's dresses: used as a substitute for merino, and especially as a material for inexpensive mourning.
A man who meddles with the domestic affairs of women; a betty.
A fine thin silk material, used for women's ruchings, dresses, etc.
A part of the headdress worn by women with the coif in the seventeenth century.
A kerchief; a covering for the head worn by women; an inner linen cap.
A place where poor women may leave their children to be taken care of during the day, while the mothers are at work.
A form of girdle worn by women in the sixteenth century.
An ornamental band or collar made of metal, beads, velvet, etc., and worn close round the throat by women.
In India, a wide piece of stuff, worn as a shawl, without cutting or sewing. It is the principal garment of women of the lower orders.
A loose upper garment of washable material worn by women while dressing. Also dressing-sack.
A peddler; specifically, one who sells women's clothes.
An outer garment worn by Maltese women, usually made of silk. See the extracts.
A chain of gold, usually set with jewels, worn on the head by women.
A kind of pinner attached to the cap or bonnet worn by women toward the close of the seventeenth century.
A loose garment with large sleeves worn by women in the sixteenth century. Also flokkard.

A cap or head-dress formerly worn by elderly women, formed like two crescents conjoined, and, by means of wire, made to stand out from the cushion on which the hair was dressed. Its name seems to come from the resemblance of its sides to wings.
In the fourteenth century and later, an outer garment used to protect the dress when riding. Apparently it was used by women only, and was the original of the modern riding-habit.
A band surrounding the forehead, worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, either alone or in combination with a cap or the like: said to have been used to prevent wrinkles.
An ornamental plaiting used for the frills and borders of women's caps, etc.
A bracelet of lacquered work, richly colored, and decorated with tin-foil, worn by women in India.
An anemic disease of young women, giving a greenish tinge to the complexion; chlorosis.
Drink, as ale or spirits, provided against a woman's confinement, and drunk by the women assembled on the occasion.
The sacrifice of women.
A light broadcloth especially adapted for women's riding-habits, but often, used for other outer garments.
One who makes habits; specifically, a maker of women's riding-habits.
A garment of muslin or similar material worn by women on the neck and shoulders, under the dress, usually having some resemblance to the collar, shirt-bosom, etc., worn by men.
A garment worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
A kerchief or other garment of linen for the head, worn especially by women.
A veil used to cover the head and usually falling behind it, as distinguished from the face-veil: such a veil is an important part of the costume of the wealthier Moslem women.
A man who meddles in women's affairs; a cotquean.
An outer garment worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, varying with the fashion, but generally a sort of close-fitting basque with short skirts.
An outer jacket worn by women; a sort of bodice without whalebone.
A lace used in the modern costume of the women of Holland.
A skirt somewhat shorter than a petticoat, worn by women when doing household work.
A plain glossy kind of silk formerly used for women's dresses.
A gesture of respect or reverence made chiefly by women by bending the knees with one foot forward and lowering the body.
A stiff flaring collar wired to stand up at the back of the head, worn by men and women in the 16th and early 17th century.
A painful swelling of the leg occurring in women after childbirth as a result of clotting and inflammation of the femoral veins.

Any of several connective tissue disorders, especially systemic lupus erythematosus, that primarily affect women of childbearing age, have a variety of clinical forms, and are characterized by red scaly skin lesions.
A sudden brief sensation of heat, often over the entire body, caused by a transient dilation of the blood vessels of the skin and experienced by some women during menopause.
Fear of or contempt for women.

An acute infection characterized by high fever, a sunburnlike rash, vomiting, and diarrhea, followed in severe cases by shock, that is caused by a toxin-producing strain of the common bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, occurring chiefly among young menstruating women who use vaginal tampons.

An abnormal curvature of the spine that is primarily manifested as a rounded hump in the upper back. Typically affecting older women, the curvature is a result of collapse of the spinal column, caused by osteoporosis.
A social system in which the father is the head of the family and men have authority over women and children.

A synthetic nonsteroidal substance, C18H20O2, having estrogenic properties and used in the treatment of prostatic cancer. It was once used to treat menstrual disorders and to prevent miscarriage but is no longer prescribed for these cases because of the occurrence of reproductive abnormalities and cancers in the offspring of women so treated.
Judaism   A partition erected in the seating section of an Orthodox synagogue to prevent the mixing of men and women.
A garment consisting of a length of printed cloth wrapped about the waist that is worn by men and women in Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Pacific islands.

An outer garment worn chiefly by women of India and Pakistan, consisting of a length of lightweight cloth with one end wrapped about the waist to form a skirt and the other draped over the shoulder or covering the head.
Creative, often sexual yearning, love, or desire: "The new playful eros means that impulses and modes from other spheres enter the relations between men and women”  ( Herbert Gold).
A support, such as a hoop, worn beneath a skirt to extend it horizontally from the waist, used by European women in the 16th and 17th centuries.
Short underpants for women or children. Often used in the plural.
Long underpants trimmed with ruffles extending below the skirt, worn by women in the mid-19th century. Often used in the plural.
A garment consisting of a rectangular piece of printed cloth worn especially in Polynesia by men and women as a wraparound skirt.
Loose-fitting trousers worn in the Far East by men and women. Often used in the plural.
A garment worn by women as a blouse front under a sweater or jacket.
February 15, observed in the United States in commemoration of the birth in 1820 of the women's suffrage leader and feminist Susan B. Anthony.
A member of the women's reserve of the U.S. Navy, organized during World War II, but now no longer a separate branch.
A society, especially a religious society, of women.
The lowest societal stratum, usually composed of the disadvantaged: "Divorced women and their children are becoming a new underclass”  ( Barbara Fisher Williamson).
January 20th, considered especially in the British Isles to be the night on which young women dream of their future husbands.
A member of the women's reserve of the U.S. Coast Guard, disbanded as a separate unit in 1946.

A modern athletic contest, now generally limited to women's competition, in which each participant competes in five track and field events, usually the 200-meter and 1,500-meter runs, the long jump, and the discus and javelin throws.
An ornamental, often jeweled, crownlike semicircle worn on the head by women on formal occasions.
Greek Mythology   The goddess of women, marriage, and childbirth; the wife and sister of Zeus.

Roman Mythology   The principal goddess of the pantheon and the wife of Jupiter, worshiped as the goddess of women, marriage, childbirth and the moon, and as the protector of the state. She came to be identified with the Greek Hera.
Mythology   The Egyptian god of music and revelry and the guardian deity of women in labor.
Power in terms of the women available to a particular group or required for a particular task.
The language of the Chukchi, noted for being pronounced differently by men and women.
A man who is amorously and gallantly attentive to women.
A movement in support of women's rights, especially the mid-twentieth century movement in North America and Europe.
A restroom for women.
Clothing for women.
A small handbag or case used by women for carrying cosmetics or toiletries.
The slight projection at the front of the throat formed by the largest cartilage of the larynx, usually more prominent in men than in women.
A piece of linen or frill of lace formerly worn by women around the neck and shoulders.
A bar patronized especially by unmarried men and women.
A set of principles applying the same standard to everyone, especially a moral code regarding the sexual behavior of both men and women.
The part of a house in Asian countries such as India and Pakistan reserved for the women of the household.
A group of people, especially women, who meet regularly for the purpose of sewing, often for charitable causes.
A person considered inferior in status or rights in comparison with some others: "He believes women . . . are second-class citizens under the Constitution”  ( Edward M. Kennedy).
An extra large or oversize clothing size, especially one for women's or children's clothing.
Discrimination based on gender, especially discrimination against women.
A ruffle or pleat of lace, muslin, or other fine fabric used for trimming women's garments.
Tight-fitting knit trousers, usually worn by women and children.
A man who enjoys and attracts the company of women.
A small netlike cap worn by women to keep the hair in place.
Sports   Either of two women officials in ice hockey who call icing and offsides, conduct face-offs, and call penalties.

An athletic contest usually limited to women in which each contestant participates in the following seven track and field events: 200-meter and 800-meter runs, 100-meter hurdles, shot put, javelin throw, high jump, and long jump.
A garment for women that ties behind the neck and across the back, leaving the arms, shoulders, and back bare.
Any of various diseases specific to women.
The administration of estrogen, especially in postmenopausal women, to relieve menopausal symptoms and to protect against osteoporosis and heart disease.
An article of women's clothing, such as a jacket, dress, or coat, that is cut so as to hang down from the shoulders and swing out and away around the hips and legs.
A crisp, smooth, plain-woven fabric with a slight sheen, made of various fibers, such as silk, rayon, or nylon, and used especially for women's garments.

A theory holding that compensation for job classifications filled chiefly by women should be the same as for those classifications filled chiefly by men if the jobs, albeit dissimilar, are regarded as having equal value. According to this theory, workers' salaries should be calculated on a scale of socioeconomic value that transcends traditional supply and demand.
A cotton shawl traditionally worn in India by men and women.
A pattern of signs and symptoms, such as fearfulness and a feeling of helplessness, commonly appearing in women who are physically and mentally abused over an extended period by a husband or partner.
A close-fitting, waist-length jacket worn by women.
A condition of hair loss in women similar to male pattern baldness, but beginning later in life and less severe.
A man who is an obsessive seducer of women.
A curved, moderately high heel used on women's shoes.
the Irish god of love and beauty; patron deity of young men and women.

a policy of making active efforts to improve the employment or educational opportunities available to members of minority groups or women; -- achieved by employers or schools by using various techniques, but excluding the use of simple quotas or outright discrimination against white males.
A kind of pin used by women to fasten the hair.

A covering for the head, worn by women, usually protecting more or less the back and sides of the head, but no part of the forehead. The shape of the bonnet varies greatly at different times; formerly the front part projected, and spread outward, like the mouth of a funnel.
One of lace, muslin, etc., for women, or infants.
a sisterhood of religious women engaged in works of mercy, esp. in nursing the sick; -- a popular designation. There are various orders of the Sisters of Charity.
A large, loosely-knitted scarf, worn by women about the head.
A mourning veil formerly worn by women.
A light housecoat worn by women.
anything beautiful; women, collectively.
The treatment of diseases peculiar to women.

syndrome resulting from a serious acute (sometimes fatal) infection associated with the presence of staphylococcus; characterized by fever and diarrhea and nausea and diffuse erythema and shock; occurs especially in menstruating women using highly absorbent tampons
cause of trichomoniasis in women and cattle and birds

syndrome resulting from a serious acute (sometimes fatal) infection associated with the presence of staphylococcus; characterized by fever and diarrhea and nausea and diffuse erythema and shock; occurs especially in menstruating women using highly absorbent tampons
a scarf worn around the head by Muslim women in Malaysia; conceals the hair but not the face
a short sleeveless undergarment for women
women's underwear
a pair of parallel bars set at different heights; used in women's gymnastics
a pair of parallel bars set at different heights; used in women's gymnastics
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Air Force
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Army
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Navy
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Air Force
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Army
a school for training men and women to become officers in the United States Navy
a cream used cosmetically (mostly by women) for softening and cleaning the skin
United States advocate of women's suffrage; in 1872 she was the first woman to run for the United States presidency (1838-1927)
a legless rectangular harpsichord; played (usually by women) in the 16th and 17th centuries
English tennis player who won many women's singles titles (born in 1945)
English tennis player who won many women's singles titles (born in 1945)
a person who forces women to become prostitutes
an outrageous rampage usually involving sexual attacks by men on women
United States advocate of temperance and women's suffrage (1839-1898)
headdress of cloth; worn over the head and around the neck and ears by medieval women
English writer and early feminist who denied male supremacy and advocated equal education for women; mother of Mary Shelley (1759-1797)
a misanthrope who dislikes women in particular
clothing that is designed for women to wear
hats for women; the wares sold by a milliner
the worship of women
a man who likes many women and has short sexual relationships with them
a man who likes many women and has short sexual relationships with them
the movement aimed at equal rights for women
the movement aimed at equal rights for women
United States advocate of women's suffrage; in 1872 she was the first woman to run for the United States presidency (1838-1927)
a loose dressing gown for women
A woman who has a crucial, often hazardous role in the forefront of an enterprise: "They are the point men and women in the industry's drive to sell wine”  ( New York Times).
A woman in charge of a religious community of women.
A respected woman having extensive experience in her field:  the grande dame of women's professional tennis.
A wide sash fastened in the back with a large flat bow, worn by women in Japan as a part of the traditional dress.
A disease occurring mostly in adult women that results from a deficiency in vitamin D or calcium and is characterized by a softening of the bones with accompanying pain and weakness.

A disease in which the bones become extremely porous, are subject to fracture, and heal slowly, occurring especially in women following menopause and often leading to curvature of the spine from vertebral collapse.
A plume formerly used to trim women's hats.
Slang   Nonsense: "the romantic hooey that always sold women's cosmetics”  ( Jerry Adler).
A loose brocaded blouse worn by Maya women in Mexico and Central America.
The headscarf worn by Muslim women, sometimes including a veil that covers the face except for the eyes.
In Jungian psychology, the masculine inner personality as present in women.
History considered from a feminist viewpoint or emphasizing the actions of women.

That part of Christian theology concerning the genesis, nature, and future of humans, especially as contrasted with the nature of God: "changing the church's anthropology to include more positive images of women”  ( Priscilla Hart).
A pubic wig for women.
The nurturing and raising of a child or children by a mother: "Because they are involved in careers and mothering, many women lead exhausting lives”  ( David E. Bloom).
A sheer fabric woven of silk or cotton and wool, used for women's apparel.
An elaborately decorated, broad-brimmed hat for women.
A restroom for women.
A lavatory for women.
A tight-fitting one-piece women's swimsuit with shoulder straps.
Informal   A man who is crude or brutal, especially toward women.
A high heel on women's shoes that is thinner than a spike heel.
A tunic worn by men and women in ancient Greece.
An establishment providing women with services that include hair treatment, manicures, and facials. Also called beauty salon, beauty shop.
A collared, usually ruffled covering for the neck and shoulders, popular in 16th-century Europe and worn especially by women.
A loose outer robe worn by women in ancient Greece. Also called peplum.
A formal ball, especially one at which young women are presented to society.
A federal program requiring that a certain percentage of government funds and contracts be reserved for businesses owned by women and members of minority groups.
A stiffly starched frilled or pleated circular collar of lace, muslin, or other fine fabric, worn by men and women in the 16th and 17th centuries.
A thong for binding the hair, worn by women in ancient Greece.
Of or relating to a university in which men and women are taught by the same faculty but in single-sex classes or on single-sex campuses.
a legless rectangular harpsichord; played (usually by women) in the 16th and 17th centuries
underpants worn by women
a pair of pants and a matching jacket worn by women
a pair of pants and a matching jacket worn by women
short underpants for women or children (usually used in the plural)
a garment worn by women in ancient Greece; cloth caught at the shoulders and draped in folds to the waist
a garment worn by women in ancient Greece; cloth caught at the shoulders and draped in folds to the waist
the monthly discharge of blood from the uterus of nonpregnant women from puberty to menopause
recurrent large circumscribed areas of subcutaneous edema; onset is sudden and it disappears within 24 hours; seen mainly in young women, often as an allergic reaction to food or drugs

a progressive form of presenile dementia found most often in middle-aged and elderly women and characterized by degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes with loss of intellectual ability and transitory aphasia
a sports outfit for women or children; usually consists of shorts and a blouse
a syndrome that occurs in many women from 2 to 14 days before the onset of menstruation
courtesy towards women
the state in which women have stopped ovulating
the state in which women have stopped ovulating

exercises for women designed to improve the ability to hold urine
a screen used in India to separate women from men or strangers
a pair of loose trousers tied by a drawstring around the waist; worn by men and women in some Asian countries
recurrent large circumscribed areas of subcutaneous edema; onset is sudden and it disappears within 24 hours; seen mainly in young women, often as an allergic reaction to food or drugs
leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana; the first woman to serve in the United States House of Representatives (1880-1973)
a fictional character in Dostoevsky's novel `Crime and Punishment'; he kills old women because he believes he is beyond the bounds of good or evil
women's stockings made from a sheer material (nylon or rayon or silk)
women's stockings made from a sheer material (nylon or rayon or silk)
a legal right guaranteed by the 15th amendment to the US Constitution; guaranteed to women by the 19th amendment
a fictional character in Dostoevsky's novel `Crime and Punishment'; he kills old women because he believes he is beyond the bounds of good or evil
a skin disease of adults (more often women) in which blood vessels of the face enlarge resulting in a flushed appearance
a pair of light loose trousers with a tight fit around the ankles; worn by women from the Indian subcontinent (usually with a kameez)
short underpants for women or children (usually used in the plural)
the traditional Hindu or Muslim system of keeping women secluded
a man with a chauvinistic belief in the inferiority of women
discrimination (usually in employment) that excludes one sex (usually women) to the benefit of the other sex
a pair of light loose trousers with a tight fit around the ankles; worn by women from the Indian subcontinent (usually with a kameez)
a derogatory term used by Jews to refer to non-Jewish women
a severe recurring vascular headache; occurs more frequently in women than men
French writer of novels about women (1873-1954)
French writer of novels about women (1873-1954)

In astrology, the state of things at the beginning of any time; particularly, the figure of the heavens at the instant of birth, specifically called the root of nativity, a term also applied to the horoscope, or ascendant. Chaucer, in the passage below, has in mind the introduction to Zahel's treatise on Elections, where it is stated that elections of fortunate times for undertakings are not much to be depended upon, except in the case of kings, who have their roots of nativity (that is, in their case there is no doubt as to the precise aspect of the heavens at the moment of birth), which roots strengthen the inferences to be drawn, especially (at least so Chaucer understands the words) in the case of a journey. When the horoscope of birth was not known, astrologers were accustomed to determine elections chiefly by the place and phase of the moon, whose influence was, however, considered debile. It appears that in the case of the lady of the story, the moon was impedited in the root of nativity (see Almansor, Prop. 35: “Cum in radice nativitatis impedietur luna,” etc.), and Mars, a planet most unfavorable to journeys, was at azir, or lord of the ascendant, at her birth, and was in the fourth, or darkest, house; so that the omens of the journey were as gloomy as they well could be.
In music, an evening song; especially, such a song sung by a lover at the window of his lady.

The cow-pea is a bean rather than a pea, having large leaves with three leaflets and seeds frequently oblong or kidney-shaped. It is commonly classed as Vigna Sinensis, but probably includes more than one natural species, the red-seeded and black-seeded varieties forming one natural group; the round-seeded ‘lady-peas’ a second; the large black-eyed and purple-eyed a third; and the mottled and speckled ‘whippoorwills,’ together with plain yellow, pinkish, and light brown a fourth. The cow-pea is an annual, its numerous varieties passing through all grades of bush, trailing, and running habit, the less rampant being better adapted to short seasons. It requires much heat and will bear no frost; hence it is most at home in the South, but varieties have been secured which will mature in 60 days, and its culture is extending northward. In the southern United States it has long been of great value, and with the introduction of mixed farming is increasingly appreciated. It is available for forage and soiling and for hay, in the latter use, when well cured, ranking with red clover; and it is one of the foremost nitrogen-gatherers. For silage it is inferior to corn or sorghum. The shelled seeds, chiefly of the ‘black-eye pea,’ are used for human food, either fresh or dried.

A name given to various things of a presumably coquettish or attractive nature: a small becoming bonnet fashionable about the middle of the nineteenth century; a lady's cap with ribbons that tied under the chin on one side with ‘kissing-strings’; a short lock of hair curled in front of each ear, etc. The name is also given to the wild pansy. See kiss-me.
The common plantain, Plantago major; also, occasionally, the lady's-mantle, Alchemilla vulgaris.
In New Zealand, a chief; a master or mistress; hence, a gentleman or lady; an aristocrat.

The pale touch-me-not or jewel-weed, Impatiens aurea; also the spotted touch-me-not, I. biflora. These plants are also sometimes called wild lady's-slipper, or simply slippers, the names all referring to the shape of the flowers.
A dressing-table; especially, a table arranged for a lady with the appurtenances of the toilet, and made somewhat ornamental, as with lace or ribbons.
The ceremonies connected with the recovery and reappearance in society of a lady of rank after the birth of a child. Compare lying-down.
l. The plant Scandix Pecten. Also called lady's-comb, shepherd's-needle, and needle chervil.

A fop or exquisite, characterized by affected refinements of dress, speech, manners, and gait, and a serious mien; hence, by an easy extension, and with less of contempt, a man given to excessive refinement of fashion in dress.

The spiritual, rational, and immortal part in man; that part of man which enables him to think, and which renders him a subject of moral government; -- sometimes, in distinction from the higher nature, or spirit, of man, the so-called animal soul, that is, the seat of life, the sensitive affections and phantasy, exclusive of the voluntary and rational powers; -- sometimes, in distinction from the mind, the moral and emotional part of man's nature, the seat of feeling, in distinction from intellect; -- sometimes, the intellect only; the understanding; the seat of knowledge, as distinguished from feeling. In a more general sense, “an animating, separable, surviving entity, the vehicle of individual personal existence.”
A man engaged in business. See Usage Note at man.

Synonyms Atonement, Reconciliation, Propitiation, Expiation, Satisfaction. By derivation and by Biblical usage atonement and reconciliation are essentially the same: two that were alienated are made at one, or put back into friendship. Atonement, however, is not now applied to the relation of man to man, except in its extra-Biblical extension, by which it means also the making of full and satisfactory amends (satisfaction) or the enduring of proper penalties (expiation) for a great wrong: as, there could be no atonement for such an outrage. As applied to the relations of God and man, atonement has been lifted into much greater dignity than any other word in the list; it is now the august, chosen, and only endeared word for the effect of the life and especially of the death of Christ in establishing right relations between God and man; reconcile and reconciliation are the principal words for this in the New Testament, atonement being used only once, and atone not at all. Propitiation is the only one of these words having exclusive reference to the feelings or purposes of the person or being offended; it is a severe word, implying slowness to relent, and is, in regard to the attitude of God toward man, chiefly a theological term. Expiation regards the guilt of the offense; it is the suffering of the penalty proper for an act (as, to make expiation for one's crime upon the scaffold), or of an adequate substituted pain. The word is general, and only barely Biblical (Num. xxxv. 33, margin, and revised version), although the fact is by the mass of Christians believed to lie in some form in the sufferings of Christ. Satisfaction in this connection means adequate amends: as, satisfaction for an insult or for damage; the word has been taken by a school in theology to express the sufficiency of the sufferings of Christ to meet the demands of the retributive justice of God.
A dialectal (especially Scotch) form of man. See man, and compare mun.
A man of straw. See man of straw , under man.
A man of fashion given to pleasuring or sport; a fashionable man about town; esp., a man of means who drives his own horse, sails his own yacht, or the like.

A man who practises obi. Also obea-man, obeah-man.
A man of literary culture; a man of letters; a literary man.
A man who speaks on behalf of another or others. See Usage Note at man.
A learned man; a man of letters; a scholar; a writer or author; originally, a man who could read, an attainment at one time confined chiefly to ecclesiastics.

In grammar, a word formed from another word, usually an appellative or generic term, to express a little thing of the kind: as, in Latin,lapillus, a little stone, from lapis, a stone; cellula, a little cell, from cella, a cell; in French, maisonnette, a little house, from maison, a house; in English, manikin, a little man, from man; rivulet, which a double diminutive, being from Latin rivulus, a diminutive of rivus, a river, with the English diminutive of rivus, a river, with the English diminutive termination -et.

Synonyms Experience, Experiment, Observation. Experience is strictly that which befalls a man, or which he goes through, while experiment is that which one actively undertakes. Observation is looking on, without necessarily having any connection with the matter: it is one thing to know of a man's goodness or of the horrors of war by observation, and quite another to know of it or them by experience. To know of a man's goodness by experiment would be to have put it to actual and intentional test. Bee practice.

Synonyms 1 and 2. Training, Discipline, Nurture, Cultivation, Instruction, Teaching, Education; indoctrination, schooling, breeding, advice, counsel. Training is the development of the mind or character or both, or some faculty, at some length, by exercise, as a soldier is trained or drilled. Discipline is essentially the same as training, but more severe. Nurture, by its derivation, expresses a tender, continuous, and protracted training, beginning at an early age. Cultivation, in the active sense, is often used of the training, discipline, or development of some single department of the nature: as, the cultivation of the understanding, the taste, the conscience. (See culture.) Teaching is the general word for the imparting of knowledge: as, the profession of teaching. Instruction has the imparting of knowledge for its object, but emphasizes, more than teaching, the employment of orderly arrangement in the things taught. Tuition is the most external or formal of these words, representing the act. Education is the largest word of all the list, having for its object, like training and discipline, the development of the powers of the man, but generally also a symmetrical development of the whole man, the mind and the moral nature, by instruction, exercise, etc. Education is the word chosen to express the best ideas that men have of the process of teaching and discipline that shall make the wisest, noblest, and most effective kind of man.

The material and spiritual universe, as distinguished from the Creator; the system of things of whieh man forms a part; creation, especially that part of it which more immediately surrounds man and affects his senses, as mountains, seas, rivers, woods, etc.: as, the beauties of nature; in a restricted sense, whatever is produced without artificial aid, and exists unchanged by man, and is thus opposed to art.
A Chinese unit of customary enumeration, in connection with certain classes of things: as, yi ko jin, a man or ‘one man’ (usually rendered in pidgin-English ‘one piecey man’).
A hominiform or man-like ape: a hypothetical animal of higher brain-capacity than the anthropoid apes, but lower than the average in man, yet approaching man in erect gait. See Pithecanthropus, 1.

The daily elimination of solids in the urine normally varies between 40 and 60 grams, of which almost 40 per cent. consists of mineral salts, the remainder of organic bodies. Of the mineral salts chlorids predominate, the amount, varying between 10 and 15 grams, being largely dependent upon the quantity ingested. As this in turn is greatly influenced by the appetite, the elimination of chlorids is, generally speaking, a fair index of the latter. Of other mineral salts sulphates and phosphates of the alkalis and the alkaline earths predominate; in addition there are traces of fluorides and nitrates. Among the organic waste products which appear in the urine of man urea is the most important. Fully 85 per cent. of the nitrogenous tissue-waste appears in this form. The daily amount varies to a great extent with the appetite and accordingly with the quantity of nitrogenous food consumed, but is on the whole fairly constant for one and the same individual: 20–30 grams per day may be regarded as a fair average, but, as overeating is on the whole very common, an elimination of 40–50 grams is not infrequently noted. In some of the lower animals, notably in birds and reptiles, uric acid is the principal nitrogenous component of the urine, while urea is found only in small amounts. In man it is unusual to meet with larger quantities than 0.6–1.0 gram in the twenty-four hours.
